title: 113_hr4161
content: The Act is titled the "21st Century STEM for Underrepresented Students Act". It focuses on STEM education for underrepresented students. The "21st Century STEM for Underrepresented Students Act" establishes a program to provide grants for research on engaging underrepresented students in grades K-8 in STEM. Grants will fund activities designed to encourage interest and skills development in STEM for these students. The "21st Century STEM for Underrepresented Students Act" funds research on engaging underrepresented K-8 students in STEM through various activities like providing programming, using hands-on learning, exposing students to STEM role models, and training educators. The "21st Century STEM for Underrepresented Students Act" aims to engage underrepresented youth in STEM through education, academic advice, real-world connections, career exposure, parental engagement, and innovative strategies like leadership skill measures to boost confidence in pursuing STEM coursework. The "21st Century STEM for Underrepresented Students Act" encourages engagement in STEM through various environments and resources, including nonprofits, educational institutions, and technology tools. Applicants must submit a detailed application describing the target audience and program justification. The program requires a detailed application with justification for targeting underrepresented students in STEM fields, recruitment and selection process, informing programming for grades K-8, promoting academic achievement, and an evaluation plan prioritizing outcome-oriented measures for grant awards. The program prioritizes applicants partnering with nonprofits experienced in increasing underrepresented students in STEM. Recipients must provide yearly evaluations, including formative and summative assessments. The Director will evaluate the program's effectiveness using common benchmarks within 3 years of enactment. The Director must use common benchmarks and assessment tools to identify best practices and materials from research. They should combine grant research with current research on serving underrepresented students in grades K-8. A report on evaluations must be submitted to Congress within 180 days, including results and recommendations for program optimization. The Director must coordinate with other Federal agencies to enhance program effectiveness and avoid duplication.
